title: Mean of Means: Human Localization with Calibration-free and Unconstrained Camera Settings (extended version)
author: Tian-Yi Zhang (Hong Kong Polytechnic University), Weng-Yu Zhang (Hong Kong Polytechnic University), Xulu Zhang (Hong Kong Polytechnic University), Jiaxin Wu (Hong Kong Polytechnic University), Xiao-Yong Wei (Sichuan University), Jiannong Cao (Hong Kong Polytechnic University), Qing Li (Hong Kong Polytechnic University), ...
relevance_why: This work presents a novel probabilistic framework for human localization that leverages distribution-based approaches, which could inspire similar methodologies in audio signal localization tasks.
background: Human localization using vision techniques aims to determine a person's position in a space based on pixel coordinates from cameras without requiring tags or specialized hardware.
contribution: This paper introduces the Mean of Means framework to solve human localization problems with limited camera settings, achieving accuracy rates exceeding 96% within a tolerance of 0.3 meters.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods relied heavily on multi-stage solvers and rigid camera setups that were costly and complex.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work simplifies the process by using a probabilistic approach that collects large-scale data through mean distributions and uses an end-to-end learning framework.

key_innovation: Utilizes a probabilistic model to treat observations of human body points as a distribution, allowing for extensive sampling and improved learning scalability.
real_world_impact: The approach has significant implications for cost-effective localization solutions in various applications, particularly in virtual environments and smart spaces where hardware limitations are a concern.
limitations: No explicit limitations are mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.Mean of Means (MoM): **Mean of Means** refers to a statistical framework introduced in the paper, where the means of distributions of observations are used to facilitate learning in a human localization task.
new_terms.Central Limit Theorem (CLT): **Central Limit Theorem** states that the distribution of the sample mean will approximate a normal distribution as the sample size becomes large, regardless of the original distribution of the data.

open_sourcing: The dataset and source code can be accessed at https://github.com/open upon acceptance.
